questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with chronic nasal obstruction, snoring, and mouth breathing. Physical examination reveals characteristic facial appearance as shown in the image and hypertrophy of the nasal turbinates. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nasal endoscopy

 

Explanation:

  • The child’s chronic nasal obstruction, snoring, mouth breathing, and facial features (adenoid facies) strongly suggest adenoid hypertrophy.
  • Nasal endoscopy is the most appropriate and accurate test for diagnosing adenoid hypertrophy as it provides a direct visual assessment of the nasopharynx and adenoid tissue.
  • It provides direct visualisation of the adenoids and accurately assesses their size and the degree of choanal obstruction.

 

Adenoid Hypertrophy

Aetiology
  • Physiological Enlargement: Common in childhood.
  • Chronic Conditions: Recurrent rhinitis, sinusitis, chronic tonsillitis, & allergies.

Clinical Features
  • Nasal Symptoms:
    • Nasal obstruction leading to mouth breathing and feeding difficulties.
    • Nasal discharge due to choanal obstruction and chronic rhinitis.
    • Sinusitis, Epistaxis & voice changes due to nasal obstruction. (Rhinolalia clausa)
  • Aural Symptoms:
    • Tubal obstruction causing retracted tympanic membrane and CHL.
    • Recurrent acute otitis media and chronic suppurative otitis media.
    • Otitis media with effusion due to intermittent eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Adenoid Facies: Characteristic facial appearance with an elongated face, open mouth, crowded upper teeth, and high-arched palate.

  • Pulmonary Hypertension: Potential due to long-standing nasal obstruction.
  • Aprosexia: Difficulty concentrating

Clinical Examination
  • External Nose: Check for skin changes indicating frequent nose rubbing.
  • Nasal Assessment: Halogen light otoscope is used for simple anterior rhinoscopy (Option C), which examines the nasal cavity but not the adenoids.
  • Adenoid Assessment:
    • Nasendoscopy: For detailed evaluation, a flexible pediatric endoscope with topical anaesthesia is preferred. It provides an accurate assessment of adenoid size in an outpatient setting.
    • Lateral Soft-Tissue Radiograph (Option B): This is useful when endoscopy is not tolerated; it correlates well with endoscopic findings.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with chronic nasal obstruction and recurrent otitis media. The physician performs endoscopy to evaluate adenoid hypertrophy. The endoscopic finding is given in the image. What is the grade of adenoid hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade III

 

Explanation:

The endoscopic image showing adenoid tissue filling from 50-75% of the choanae corresponds to Grade III.

 

Grading of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

  • Grade I: Adenoid occupies 0-25% of the choanal space.
  • Grade II: Adenoid occupies 25-50% of the choanal space.
  • Grade III: Adenoid occupies 50-75% of the choanal space.
  • Grade IV: Adenoid occupies >75% of the choanal space,

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with persistent nasal obstruction and recurrent ear infections has not improved with decongestants and antihistamines. What is the most appropriate next step for definitive management currently being used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endoscopic debridement

 

Explanation:

Given the scenario where a child with persistent nasal obstruction and recurrent ear infections has not responded to Medical management, the most appropriate next step for definitive management is Endoscopic debridement.

 

Management of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

Medical Management: (For Mild Cases initially)
  • Breathing exercises
  • Decongestant nasal drops
  • Antihistamines for any nasal allergies
  • Topical Nasal Steroids (Option C) may reduce adenoid size and improve related symptoms.

Surgical Intervention: (Adenoidectomy)
  • Traditional Methods: Blind curettage adenoidectomy (Option A) remains common, but it has disadvantages, including unpredictable bleeding and poor access to the choanal adenoid. Hence, Endoscopic management is currently preferred.
  • Direct Vision Techniques:
    • Suction Diathermy
    • Endoscopic Coblation/Microdebridement (Option B) involves using endoscopy to visualise and allows for precise removal of obstructive adenoid tissue, addressing the underlying issue directly.
    • KTP Laser: Associated with a higher risk of nasopharyngeal stenosis, while the gold laser has not shown this risk.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child was scheduled for elective adenoidectomy but developed an acute upper respiratory infection the day before the surgery. The child has no cleft palate or bleeding disorders. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Delay the surgery until the infection resolves
Start antibiotics and proceed with surgery
Discharge the patient with medical management

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delay the surgery until the infection resolves

 

Explanation:

Elective surgery, including adenoidectomy, should be postponed in children with an acute upper respiratory infection to minimise complications.

Indications & Contraindications of Adenoidectomy

Indications
  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnea, or speech abnormalities (rhinolalia clausa).
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis.
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion linked to adenoid hyperplasia.
  • Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM associated with adenoiditis.
  • Preventing recurrence of dental malocclusion after orthodontic treatment.

Contraindications
  • Cleft palate or submucous palate (risk of velopharyngeal insufficiency).
  • Hemorrhagic diathesis.
  • Acute upper respiratory infection.

 

Proceed with adenoidectomy as planned (Option A): Incorrect because an acute URI poses increased anesthesia risk.

Start antibiotics and proceed with surgery (Option C): Incorrect; antibiotics do not eliminate anesthetic risk during URI.

Discharge the patient with medical management (Option D): Incorrect because surgery is elective, not emergent; focus is on timing, not discharge.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child undergoes an adenoidectomy. Following the surgery, the child is monitored for potential complications. Which of the following is not a recognised complication of adenoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chronic Otitis Media

 

Explanation:

Chronic Otitis Media is a condition that might be associated with adenoid hypertrophy and can be improved by adenoidectomy, but it is not a complication of the surgery itself.

 

Complications of Adenoidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage: Immediate postoperative bleeding may require postnasal packing.
  • Risk of injury: Eustachian tubes (Option D), pharyngeal musculature, and vertebrae. Special care for Down’s syndrome patients due to potential atlantoaxial instability.
  • Grisel’s Syndrome (Option B): Neck pain and torticollis, possibly from atlantoaxial dislocation.
  • Velopharyngeal Insufficiency (Option A): Check for submucous cleft palate preoperatively.
  • Nasopharyngeal Stenosis: Due to scarring.
  • Recurrence: Regrowth of adenoid tissue left behind.

 

Adenoidectomy

Anesthesia

General with oral endotracheal intubation.

Position

Rose’s position.

Procedure
  • Preparation: Insert Boyle-Davis mouth gag. Examine the nasopharynx with a tongue depressor and digital palpation.
  • Adenoid Removal: Use a curette with a guard to engage and remove adenoids. Lateral masses are removed with smaller curettes, and any remaining tissue is extracted with punch forceps.
  • Hemostasis: Achieved by packing the area. Persistent bleeding may require electrocoagulation or a postnasal pack for 24 hours.

Endoscopic Techniques
  • Debrider: For precise removal under endoscopic control.
  • Coblation: Uses radiofrequency to create a plasma field for removal.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chronic nasopharyngeal discomfort and intermittent nasal obstruction. Imaging studies reveal a midline cystic structure in the nasopharynx. The patient is diagnosed with Thornwaldt's disease. Which of the following anatomical remnants is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Remnant of the notochord

Explanation:

The persistence of notochordal remnants can lead to the formation of midline cystic structures in the nasopharynx, which is consistent with Thornwaldt's disease.

 

Thornwaldt's disease

  • Thornwaldt’s bursa is an epithelial-lined recess in the nasopharynx, representing a remnant of the attachment of the notochord to the endoderm of the pharynx during early development.
  • Thornwaldt’s disease is characterised by a midline nasopharyngeal cyst resulting from the persistence of a remnant of the notochord.
  • It presents with persistent postnasal discharge or crusting, nasal obstruction, dull occipital headache, low-grade fever, recurrent sore throat, obstruction to the eustachian tube and serous otitis media.

Remnant of Rathke’s pouch (Option A): Rathke’s pouch is an embryonic structure that forms the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland. Remnants of Rathke’s pouch typically result in Rathke’s cleft cysts, which are located in the sellar region of the skull and are not related to the nasopharynx.

Remnants of pharyngeal clefts (Option B) usually lead to branchial cleft cysts or sinuses, which are typically located along the lateral neck or anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They are not associated with midline cystic lesions in the nasopharynx.

Persistence of the Thyroglossal Duct (Option D): The thyroglossal duct is a temporary embryonic structure that connects the thyroid gland to the base of the tongue. It normally obliterates after development, but when it fails to do so, it can form a thyroglossal cyst, which typically appears as a midline neck mass.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a fever. On examination, the child has enlarged tonsils with visible crypts. Which of the following anatomical features of the palatine tonsils is not true?

choices.text: They are covered by stratified squamous epithelium with crypts.
They receive blood mainly from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.
A fibrous capsule with loose areolar tissue covers the lateral surface.
Lymphatic drainage primarily involves the lower deep cervical nodes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lymphatic drainage primarily involves the lower deep cervical nodes.

Explanation:

The lymphatic drainage of the palatine tonsils primarily flows into the upper deep cervical nodes, not the lower deep cervical nodes.

 

Anatomy of Palatine tonsils

Location

Lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars.

Surface Extensions

Upwards into the soft palate, downwards into the base of the tongue, and anteriorly into the palatoglossal arch.

Medial Surface Epithelium
  • Stratified squamous epithelium with crypts. (Option A)
  • Crypta magna, or intratonsillar cleft, is located near the upper part of the tonsil.

Lateral Surface

It is covered by a fibrous capsule separated from the tonsil bed by loose areolar tissue. (Option C)

Tonsil Bed Muscles

Formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

Arterial Supply
  • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (main supply) (Option B)
  • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Dorsal linguae branches of the lingual artery
  • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery.

Venous Drainage

It drains into the paratonsillar vein, which joins the common facial vein and the pharyngeal venous plexus.

Lymphatic Drainage

Flows into the upper deep cervical nodes.

Sensory Nerve Supply

Lesser palatine branches of the sphenopalatine ganglion (CN V) and the glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: During a tonsillectomy, injury to structures within the tonsillar bed may result in significant complications. Which of the following structures is not directly associated with the tonsillar bed but can be affected by deep dissection or improper technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypoglossal nerve

Explanation:

The hypoglossal nerve is not directly associated with the tonsillar bed, but improper or deep dissection could affect it, although it is anatomically more distant compared to the other structures listed.

 

Structures forming Tonsillar bed

Muscles forming the tonsillar bed
  • Superior Constrictor Muscle
  • Styloglossus Muscle

Structures close to the tonsillar bed (outside the superior constrictor muscle)
  • Facial Artery (Tonsillar Branch): Major blood supply to the tonsils, at risk for haemorrhage during surgery.
  • Paratonsillar Vein: Venous drainage of the tonsil, risk of bleeding during tonsillectomy.
  • Submandibular Salivary Gland
  • Posterior Belly of Digastric Muscle
  • Medial Pterygoid Muscle
  • Mandible
  • Glossopharyngeal Nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the tonsils.

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presents with a sore throat and fever. Upon examination, the physician observes that the tonsils are enlarged and other findings as in the image below. Which type of tonsillitis does this clinical presentation indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acute membranous tonsillitis

Explanation:

The presence of a thick, whitish membrane on the tonsils in the image is indicative of acute membranous tonsillitis.
 

Type of Acute Tonsillitis

Description

Clinical Features

Acute Catarrhal Tonsillitis (Option A)

Most common type and is a part of generalised pharyngitis, often viral.

Redness and mild swelling of the tonsils; sore throat; no pus or membrane.

Acute Follicular Tonsillitis (Option B)

Infection involves the tonsillar crypts that are filled with purulent material.

Yellowish spots at the openings of the crypts; sore throat; fever.

Acute Parenchymatous Tonsillitis (Option D)

It affects the substance of the tonsil and leads to uniform enlargement and redness.

Uniformly enlarged, red tonsils; significant swelling; no membrane.

Acute Membranous Tonsillitis

Progression from acute follicular tonsillitis; exudate from crypts forms a membrane on the tonsil surface.

The whitish or greyish membrane covering the tonsils; severe sore throat; fever.

 

Chronic tonsillitis with tonsilloliths (Option C) presents with persistent symptoms like halitosis and recurrent infections, not acute fever and enlarged tonsils. The patient has acute symptoms, more suggestive of acute membranous tonsillitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing for 3 days. On examination, there is bilateral tonsillar enlargement with purulent exudate. A rapid strep test is positive. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe paracetamol and monitor for 48 hours.
Initiate a 7-10 day course of oral amoxicillin.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Initiate a 7-10 day course of oral amoxicillin.

Explanation:

For a child with confirmed streptococcal tonsillitis, (the most common cause of acute tonsillitis being group A Streptococcus) the appropriate management is to prescribe a full course of oral antibiotics, typically amoxicillin, for 7-10 days to treat the infection and prevent complications.

Management of Acute tonsillitis

Management Aspect

Treatment/Action

General Supportive Care

Bed Rest and adequate fluids to aid in comfort and prevent complications.

Symptomatic Relief

Analgesics (e.g., Aspirin, Paracetamol) to provide relief from pain and fever. (Option A)

Antibiotic therapy
  • Antibiotics are prescribed to treat bacterial infections, primarily Streptococcus.
    • First-line Antibiotics: Penicillin, Ampicillin, Amoxicillin, Amoxicillin with Clavulanic acid.
    • Alternative: Erythromycin (for penicillin allergy).
  • Treatment duration is typically 7-10 days.

 

Administer intravenous antibiotics (Option C) are typically reserved for patients unable to tolerate oral medications due to severe vomiting or inability to swallow, or showing signs of severe infection or complications such as an abscess or sepsis.

Perform an immediate tonsillectomy (Option D) is indicated for recurrent or chronic tonsillitis, not for acute cases. Immediate tonsillectomy is usually reserved for severe obstructive tonsillar hypertrophy and peritonsillar abscess unresponsive to medical therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a recurrent sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and foul-smelling breath for the past year. He reports episodes of fever and malaise. Examination reveals enlarged tonsils that on pressing the crypt , pus oozes out and tender anterior cervical lymph nodes. What is the most likely sign seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Irwin moore sign

 

Explanation:

Irwin Moore Sign is characteristic of chronic tonsillitis, where pressing the anterior tonsillar pillar expresses pus from the crypts of the tonsils. This occurs due to the accumulation of debris and bacteria in the crypts, leading to chronic inflammation.

 

Chronic Tonsillitis

Aspect

Explanation

Definition

Persistent inflammation of the tonsils due to recurrent infections or unresolved acute tonsillitis.

Aetiology

Recurrent bacterial (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus) or viral infections.

Pathophysiology

Trapped debris in tonsillar crypts leads to chronic inflammation, hypertrophy, and fibrosis.

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent sore throat
  • Halitosis
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Enlarged tonsils with cryptic pus
  • Tender cervical lymphadenopathy

Key Sign

Irwin Moore Sign: Expression of pus from tonsillar crypts on pressing the anterior tonsillar pillar.

Diagnosis

Clinical based on history of recurrent infections, physical exam findings, throat culture or RADT if needed.

Management
  • Conservative: Antibiotics for acute infections, Symptomatic relief by gargling with warm/salt water and NSAIDs (for pain and inflammation).
  • Surgical: Tonsillectomy
    • It is indicated for patients with recurrent infections,usually defined as
      • ≥ 7 episodes of tonsillitis in 1 year, or
      • ≥ 5 episodes/year for 2 consecutive years, or
      • ≥ 3 episodes/year for 3 consecutive years

or those with chronic tonsillitis refractory to medical management.

  • It is also recommended for cases with complications such as peritonsillar abscess, or if chronic tonsillitis is significantly affecting the patient’s quality of life.

Complications

Peritonsillar abscess, rheumatic fever, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Griesinger’s Sign (Option A) is characterised by pain, swelling, and tenderness over the mastoid process and is caused by the spread of infection from the middle ear to the mastoid air cells, leading to thrombophlebitis. It is indicative of mastoiditis with thrombosis of the sigmoid sinus and may suggest intracranial complications like lateral sinus thrombosis.

 

Battle's Sign (Option B) refers to ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process and is seen in basilar skull fractures, particularly involving the temporal bone.

Cottle's Sign (Option C) or Cottle test is used to assess nasal obstruction. Lateral traction of the cheek (Cottle manoeuvre) improves airflow if the obstruction is due to nasal valve collapse or dysfunction, one of the common causes of functional nasal obstruction.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with recurrent sore throat, recent high-grade fever, and breathing difficulties during sleep. He is scheduled for a tonsillectomy. Which among the following is a contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acute tonsillitis

 

Explanation:

Acute tonsillitis involves active infection and inflammation of the tonsils, which increases the risk of bleeding, poor wound healing, and postoperative infection. Surgeons typically wait for the infection to resolve with antibiotics before performing a tonsillectomy.

 

Contraindications of Tonsillectomy

Absolute Contraindications

Relative contraindications
  • Polio epidemic
  • Von Willebrand's disease or Bleeding disorders
  • Acute infections
  • Hemoglobin < 10 g%
  • Uncontrolled systemic diseases, like HTN, DM, and Asthma.
  • Age of the child is <3 years
  • During menstruation
  • Recent acute upper respiratory tract infection
  • Submucous cleft palate

 

 

Indications of Tonsillectomy

Absolute Indications

Relative Indications
  • Recurrent Tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (Option C)
  • Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures
  • Tonsils interfering with speech, swallowing or breathing
  • Suspicion of malignancy (Option B)
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (Option A)
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis
  • Diphtheria carriers,not responding to antibiotics.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl, who had a tonsillectomy 6 days ago, presents with high fever, throat pain, and swelling in the neck. All the following are immediate complications of this surgery except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Parapharyngeal abscess

 

Explanation:

Parapharyngeal abscess is not an immediate complication but can develop later as a secondary issue, often due to an infection. It typically presents days to weeks after the surgery, rather than immediately.

 

Complications of Tonsillectomy

Immediate complications

Delayed Complication
  • Primary Hemorrhage, it happens at the time of surgery. (Option A)
  • Reactionary Hemorrhage which happens within 24 hours of the surgery (Option C)
  • Injury to tonsillar pillars, uvula, soft palate, teeth, tongue or superior constrictor muscle
  • Aspiration of blood
  • Facial oedema, particularly of eyelids (Option B)
  • Surgical emphysema (not very common)
  • Secondary Hemorrhage, it happens anywhere between 5 to 10 days post-Op
  • Infection of tonsillar fossa might lead to para-pharyngeal abscess or otitis media.
  • Aspiration of blood, mucus or tissue fragments.
  • Scarring in soft palate and pillars
  • Tonsillar remnants which may get repeatedly infected.
  • Hypertrophy of lingual tonsil.

questions.text: A 15 years old female who had a tonsillectomy 16 hours ago is currently under post-op monitoring, suddenly begins to bleed from the mouth and is noted to have hypotension with tachycardia. What is the most likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Slipping of ligature

 

Explanation:

  • The most likely cause of bleeding in this scenario is the slipping of a ligature. During tonsillectomy, ligatures control bleeding from the tonsillar bed.
  • If a ligature slips or becomes dislodged, it can lead to sudden bleeding, often occurring within the first 24 hours post-operatively (Reactionary hemorrhage). This can result in hypotension and tachycardia due to blood loss.

 

Hemorrhage is the most common complication post-tonsillectomy and is of 3 types based on the duration:

Type of Hemorrhage

Primary Hemorrhage

Reactionary Hemorrhage

Secondary Hemorrhage

Duration of occurrence

Immediate complication, occur at the time of surgery.

Happens within first 24 hours post surgery (Immediate complication)

Seen between 5th to 10th postoperative day.

Causes

Inadequate hemostasis or injury to the vessels (Option C)

Slipping of ligature (Option D), hypertension or the dislodging of clot.

Infection (Option B) or premature separation of the membrane (Option A)

Management

Application of pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Initially, remove the clot and apply pressure or use a vasoconstrictor. If these measures are ineffective, proceed with ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Initially by Antibiotics, if bleeding persists re-exploration is done.
